background: the part of a picture, scene, or design that forms a setting for the main figures or objects, or appears furthest from the viewer
facade: the principal front of a building, that faces on to a street or open space
window: an opening in the wall or roof of a building or vehicle, fitted with glass in a frame to admit light or air and allow people to see out.
door: a hinged, sliding, or revolving barrier at the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle, or in the framework of a cupboard.
cornice: an ornamental moulding round the wall of a room just below the ceiling.
sill: a shelf or slab of stone, wood, or metal at the foot of a window opening or doorway.
balcony: a platform enclosed by a wall or balustrade on the outside of a building, with access from an upper-floor window or door.
blind: unable to see because of injury, disease, or a congenital condition.
deco: the predominant decorative art style of the 1920s and 1930s, characterized by precise and boldly delineated geometric shapes and strong colours and used most notably in household objects and in architecture.
molding: form (an object) out of malleable material.
pillar: a tall vertical structure of stone, wood, or metal, used as a support for a building, or as an ornament or monument.
shop: a building or part of a building where goods or services are sold.
